tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the natural frequency, which involves understanding the dynamics of a hinged bar supported by a spring. It requires multiple steps to determine the equivalent stiffness and mass, and then applying the natural frequency formula. It integrates concepts of mechanics and vibration.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The bar is uniform, length 1 m, mass 3 kg, hinged at F on the left and supported by a vertical spring of stiffness k = 100 N/m at the right end G. For small rotation \(	heta\) about the hinge, the right end moves vertically by \(y_G = L	heta\). The spring force is \(F_s = k y_G = k L 	heta\), giving a restoring moment about F: \(M_s = F_s L = k L^2 	heta\). This is an equivalent rotational stiffness \(K_	heta = k L^2\). The bar is uniform, so its mass moment of inertia about the hinge at one end is \(I_F =  rac{1}{3} m L^2\). The rotational equation of motion is \(I_F \ddot{	heta} + K_	heta 	heta = 0\). Thus \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_	heta / I_F} = \sqrt{(k L^2) / (	frac{1}{3} m L^2)} = \sqrt{3k/m}\). Substituting \(k = 100\,	ext{N/m}\) and \(m = 3\,	ext{kg}\): 

\(\omega_n = \sqrt{3 	imes 100 / 3} = \sqrt{100} = 10\,	ext{rad/s}.\)

This matches the official key range 10 to 10.

step_by_step: Identify the motion: the rigid bar rotates about hinge F with small angle \(\theta\). The spring at G provides a vertical restoring force.
Relate end displacement to rotation: for small rotation, vertical displacement of G is \(y_G = L\theta\), where \(L = 1\,\text{m}\).
Compute spring restoring moment about F: spring force is \(F_s = k y_G = k L \theta\); moment is \(M_s = F_s L = k L^2 \theta\). So equivalent rotational stiffness is \(K_\theta = k L^2\).
Find mass moment of inertia of the uniform bar about hinge at one end: \(I_F = \frac{1}{3} m L^2\) with \(m = 3\,\text{kg}, L = 1\,\text{m}\).
Write rotational equation of motion: \(I_F \ddot{\theta} + K_\theta \theta = 0\), which is of the standard SDOF form \(I \ddot{\theta} + K_\theta \theta = 0\).
Compute natural frequency: \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_\theta / I_F} = \sqrt{(k L^2) / (\tfrac{1}{3} m L^2)} = \sqrt{3k/m} = \sqrt{3 \times 100 / 3} = 10\,\text{rad/s}.\)

topic.name: Structural Vibration of Discrete Systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3 Structures -> Structural dynamics and aeroelasticity -> Free vibration of discrete systems

concepts.name: Equivalent rotational stiffness from linear spring
Mass moment of inertia of a uniform bar

essential: Newton\'s second law for rotation (sum of moments equals I alpha)
Mass moment of inertia of slender bars about an end
Hooke\'s law and linear spring force-displacement relation
Equation of motion and natural frequency of SDOF systems
helpful: Small-angle kinematics relating linear and angular displacement
Concept of equivalent stiffness in rotational systems

Main Concept: requires: Newton\'s second law for rotation
requires: Mass moment of inertia of a rigid bar
enables: Analysis of more complex multi-degree-of-freedom structural vibration problems

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that the bar is rigid and rotates, not bends
Needs correct use of bar inertia about hinge and conversion of linear spring stiffness to rotational stiffness

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.chapter_title: Free Vibration of Single Degree of Freedom Systems
textbook_references.section: Rotational systems and rigid body vibration
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a rigid body rotating about a fixed axis with attached springs, the equation of motion is obtained by summing moments about the axis and expressing linear spring forces as equivalent moments K_i l_i^2 \theta.

textbook_references.author: T. H. G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Problems on beams and frames idealized as SDOF systems illustrate how to compute natural frequencies using equivalent stiffness and inertia.

video_references.professor: Prof. S. K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Natural frequency of a pivoted rigid bar with springs and masses (rotational SDOF system)

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Kinematics of rotation \u2192 Spring force and moment \u2192 Equivalent rotational stiffness \u2192 Inertia about hinge \u2192 Equation of motion \u2192 Natural frequency
key_insights: Treat the bar as a rigid body rotating about the hinge, not as a flexible beam.
Convert the linear spring stiffness at distance L into a rotational stiffness k L^2.
Use the standard SDOF formula \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_\theta / I}\).

formulas_principles.name: Small-angle linear-angular displacement relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Valid for small rotations of a rigid bar about a hinge
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates bar rotation to vertical displacement at the spring location

formulas_principles.name: Linear spring force law
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives spring force from end displacement

formulas_principles.name: Mass moment of inertia of slender rod about end
formulas_principles.conditions: Uniform slender rod rotating about an axis through one end and perpendicular to length
formulas_principles.relevance: Provides inertia term in rotational equation of motion

formulas_principles.name: Natural frequency of rotational SDOF system
formulas_principles.conditions: Undamped free vibration of a single-degree-of-freedom rotational system
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to compute the natural frequency once stiffness and inertia are known

industry_examples: Control surface hinge dynamics: elevator or aileron panels supported by springs or actuators can be approximated as rigid bars with rotational stiffness.
Landing gear doors or access panels that are spring-loaded and rotate about hinges.
specific_systems: Aircraft flap or spoiler panels modeled as rigid bodies on torsional springs for flutter and vibration analysis.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Estimating natural frequencies of hinged components helps avoid resonance with aerodynamic or engine excitation, which could cause fatigue or control issues.

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating the bar as a point mass at its center instead of using the correct mass moment of inertia about the hinge.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall translational SDOF formulas more readily and try to force-fit them.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Whenever rotation about a hinge is involved, explicitly write the rotational equation using I and moments, not m and forces.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to wrong dynamic model and incorrect natural frequency.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using spring stiffness k directly in \(\omega_n = \sqrt{k/m}\) without converting to rotational stiffness.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They forget that the spring force acts at a distance from the hinge and creates a moment.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always convert linear stiffness at distance L to rotational stiffness k L^2 when dealing with rotation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates or overestimates frequency depending on how mass is modeled.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using wrong inertia formula, e.g., \(I = \frac{1}{12} m L^2\) (about center) instead of \(\frac{1}{3} m L^2\) (about end).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember one standard formula and apply it blindly.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check the rotation axis: center vs end. Use parallel-axis theorem if needed.
common_mistakes.consequence: Frequency error by factor of about \(\sqrt{4} = 2\).

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring that the bar is rigid and trying to use beam bending formulas (EI, mode shapes).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They associate any bar with beam theory without reading 'rigid bar' carefully.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline keywords like 'rigid bar' and 'hinged' to decide between rigid-body and elastic vibration models.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Rotational stiffness from a linear spring at distance L: \(K_\theta = k L^2\)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever converting linear spring stiffness to rotational stiffness about a hinge.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Inertia of a uniform rod about an end: \(I = \tfrac{1}{3} m L^2\)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Recall correct inertia formula for slender bar rotating about one end.

flashcards.front: What is the mass moment of inertia of a uniform slender bar of mass m and length L about an axis through one end, perpendicular to its length?
flashcards.back: For a uniform slender bar about an end: \(I = \frac{1}{3} m L^2\).

flashcards.front: A linear spring of stiffness k is attached at distance L from a hinge. What is the equivalent rotational stiffness about the hinge?
flashcards.back: Equivalent rotational stiffness: \(K_\theta = k L^2\), since moment = k(L\theta)L = kL^2\theta.

flashcards.front: Write the equation of motion for a rigid bar rotating about a fixed hinge with rotational stiffness K_θ and inertia I.
flashcards.back: The undamped free-vibration equation is: \(I \ddot{\theta} + K_\theta \theta = 0\).

flashcards.front: Uniform rigid bar, m = 3 kg, L = 1 m, hinged at one end, spring k = 100 N/m at other end. Find \(\omega_n\).
When should you NOT use \(\omega_n = \sqrt{k/m}\) directly for a bar-spring system?
flashcards.back: When the bar rotates about a hinge (rigid-body rotation). You must use rotational form \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_\theta/I}\) with \(K_\theta = kL^2\) and inertia about the hinge.

real_world_context.application: Vibration of hinged aircraft panels supported by springs or actuators
real_world_context.industry_example: An access door on an aircraft fuselage held by a torsion spring can be modeled as a rigid panel rotating about its hinge with equivalent rotational stiffness.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of natural frequency can lead to resonance with engine or aerodynamic excitations, causing noise, fatigue, or failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan for keywords like 'rigid bar', 'hinged', and a single spring. Recognize it as a simple rotational SDOF problem; write inertia and stiffness quickly and plug into \(\omega_n = \sqrt{K_\theta/I}\).
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that stiffer spring or lighter bar means higher frequency; use order-of-magnitude: here k/m ~ 30, so \(\omega_n\) is around \(\sqrt{30} \approx 5.5\) to \(\sqrt{100} = 10\). Choose a simple integer like 10 if inertia about end is small.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute to model (I and K_θ), 1 minute to compute and check units.

search_keywords: mass moment of inertia uniform rod about end
single degree of freedom rotational system
GATE AE structural vibration rigid bar
S S Rao rotational vibration example

alternative_methods.name: Energy method (Rayleigh quotient) for rigid-body rotation
alternative_methods.description: Assume small harmonic rotation \(\theta(t) = \Theta \sin \omega t\). Compute maximum kinetic energy using \(T = \tfrac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^2\) and maximum potential energy using spring extension at G: \(V = \tfrac{1}{2} k (L\Theta)^2\). Equate \(T_{max} = V_{max}\) to obtain \(\omega^2 = K_\theta / I\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Uses energy, avoids writing differential equations; good for more complex but still SDOF systems. Cons: Requires recognizing SDOF and computing energies correctly.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when multiple springs or masses are present but motion is still dominated by a single generalized coordinate.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Uses concepts of moments, rigid-body rotation, and mass moment of inertia from statics and dynamics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mechanical Vibrations: Core SDOF vibration modeling, directly from introductory vibration courses.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aeroelasticity: Rigid-body modes of control surfaces with torsional springs are basic building blocks for aeroelastic models.

deeper_dive_topics: Coupled bending-torsion vibration of beams and wings
Modal analysis of multi-degree-of-freedom rigid-body systems
Aeroelastic flutter of control surfaces modeled as hinged rigid bodies with springs
Effect of damping on rotational SDOF systems

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Structural dynamics and aeroelasticity: Free vibration of discrete systems
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent basic SDOF rigid-body vibration question that reinforces conversion between linear and rotational stiffness and use of mass moment of inertia.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general treatment of SDOF rotational systems, equivalent rotational stiffness (k l^2), and natural frequency formulas, which align well with this problem. However, the exact geometry and numerical values are from the question itself, so detailed computation relied on internal reasoning.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the static deflection of the bar end under its own weight plus spring and then small oscillations about that equilibrium.
Modify the problem to include an additional point mass at some distance along the bar and ask for the new natural frequency.
Introduce damping in the spring support and ask for the damped natural frequency and logarithmic decrement.
Replace the rigid bar with a flexible beam (EI given) and ask for the first bending natural frequency using an approximate SDOF model.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A uniform rigid bar of mass 3 kg is hinged at point F, and supported by a spring of stiffness k=100 N/m, as shown in the figure. The natural frequency of free vibration of the system is ____rad/s (answer in integer).
